en_second_half: words that Basil’s friend had said to him—words spoken by chance, no doubt, and with wilful paradox in them—had touched some secret chord that had never been touched before, but that he felt was now vibrating and throbbing to curious pulses.

en_results_raw: words that he had spoken, though they had been spoken in a low tone, had been like a key turning in a lock, and the sound of them still lingered in his mind. He felt a sense of liberation, as if a weight had been lifted from his shoulders, and a strange, unaccustomed lightness had taken its place. The room around him seemed to have changed, the shadows deepening and the colors brightening, and he felt a sense of wonder at the transformation. It was as if he had been living in a world of gray, and suddenly he had been transported to a world of vibrant color. He took a step forward, and then another, his feet seeming to move of their own accord, and his heart pounding in his chest. He felt alive, and yet he felt lost, as if he was navigating uncharted territory. The few words he had spoken had unlocked a door, and he was stepping through it, into a new and unknown world.

Mientras tanto, la abeja siguió trabajando, sin parar, hasta que finalmente se despegó de la flor y se perdió en el aire, dejando a Dorian Gray con una sensación de fascinación y admiración por la pequeña criatura que había estado observando.

en_first_half: “It is an interesting question,” said Lord Henry, who found an exquisite pleasure in playing on the lad’s unconscious egotism, “an extremely interesting question. I fancy that the true explanation is this: It often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an inartistic manner that they hurt us by their crude violence, their absolute incoherence, their absurd want of meaning, their entire lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of sheer brute force, and we revolt against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy that possesses artistic elements of beauty crosses our lives. If these elements of beauty are real, the whole thing simply appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather we are both. We watch ourselves,
en_second_half: and the mere wonder of the spectacle enthralls us. In the present case, what is it that has really happened? Some one has killed herself for love of you. I wish that I had ever had such an experience. It would have made me in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me—there have not been very many, but there have been some—have always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they to care for me. They have become stout and tedious, and when I meet them, they go in at once for reminiscences. That awful memory of woman! What a fearful thing it is! And what an utter intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colour of life, but one should never remember its details. Details are always vulgar.”
en_results: , and we are also the actors, caught up in the drama, our emotions heightened, our senses on fire. The tragedy becomes a work of art, a masterpiece that transcends the mundane and speaks directly to our souls. It is then that we realize that the true power of art lies not in its ability to imitate life, but in its capacity to transform it, to elevate it, to make it beautiful. And it is this transformation that Lord Henry was referring to when he spoke of the "real tragedies of life." And it is this that makes life worth
en_results_raw: watch ourselves, and we are also the actors, caught up in the drama, our emotions heightened, our senses on fire. The tragedy becomes a work of art, a masterpiece that transcends the mundane and speaks directly to our souls. It is then that we realize that the true power of art lies not in its ability to imitate life, but in its capacity to transform it, to elevate it, to make it beautiful. And it is this transformation that Lord Henry was referring to when he spoke of the "real tragedies of life." He was not talking about the brutal, the mundane, the everyday events that fill our lives, but about those rare, sublime moments that touch our hearts and minds, that make us see the world in a new light, that make us see ourselves in a new way. And it is this that makes life worth living, this that makes it worth experiencing, this that makes it worth creating art about. For in the end, it is not the trivial, the mundane, the everyday that we remember, but the moments of beauty, the moments of tragedy, the moments that touch our souls and make us human. And it is these moments that Lord Henry was trying to convey when he spoke of the "real tragedies of life." He was speaking of the moments that make us feel alive, that make us feel connected to something greater than ourselves, that make us feel a part of the grand tapestry of human experience. And it is these moments that we must strive to capture, to create, to preserve, for it is in these moments that we find the true meaning of life, the true purpose of art.

Alguien se ha matado por amor tuyo. Me gustaría haber tenido alguna vez una experiencia semejante. Me hubiera hecho enamorarme del amor para el resto de mi vida. Las personas que me han adorado (no han sido muchas, pero sí algunas), siempre han insistido en seguir viviendo después de que yo dejase de quererlas y ellas dejaran de quererme a mí. Se han vuelto corpulentas y tediosas, y cuando me encuentro con ellas se lanzan inmediatamente a los recuerdos. ¡Ah, esa terrible memoria de las mujeres! ¡Qué cosa más espantosa! ¡Y qué total estancamiento intelectual revela! Se deben absorberlos colores de la vida, pero nunca recordar los detalles. Los detalles siempre son vulgares.

It was to be a new Hedonism, one that would not be bound by the conventional morals of the time, but would instead seek to indulge in the pleasures of the senses, to explore the depths of human experience, and to live life to the fullest. It was to be a philosophy that would celebrate the individual, that would encourage people to be themselves, to express themselves freely, and to live life on their own terms. And it was to be a movement that would not be afraid to challenge the status quo, to question the established norms, and to push the boundaries of what was considered acceptable. It was to be a revolution of the spirit, a revolution that would free people from the shackles of convention and allow them to live life as they truly desired. And at the heart of this new Hedonism would be the pursuit of beauty, the pursuit of pleasure, and the pursuit of happiness, for its own sake, and not for the sake of some higher moral or spiritual goal.

en_second_half: is very rich in curious effects of that kind. Me acerqué un poco más, sin querer llamar la atención, y escuché algunas de las palabras que el predicador estaba pronunciando. Me parecieron extrañas y contradictorias, pero al mismo tiempo, había algo en ellas que me hizo sentir una especie de curiosidad, una sensación de que estaba escuchando algo que no debía escuchar. Me pregunté si sería posible que aquel hombre estuviera diciendo algo de verdad, algo que pudiera cambiar la forma en que veíamos el mundo. Me sentí un poco incómodo, como si estuviera invadiendo un territorio que no era el mío, y me di la vuelta para alejarme, pero no pude evitar escuchar una última frase que el predicador gritó con una voz que parecía resonar en mi interior: "¿Qué es lo que hace que un hombre sea verdaderamente vivo?"
